p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 33rd report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the
1. The committee resolved to present the following 40 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 21 petitioners—requesting an increase to the rate of Goods and Services Tax imposed on purchases made through certain online platforms (EN6550)
From 8 petitioners—requesting increased support for higher education programs (EN6551)
From 220 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to allegations of domestic violence (EN6552)
From 34 petitioners—requesting that a proposal to provide funding to rugby league in Papua New Guinea be halted (EN6553)
From 5 petitioners—regarding the classification of koalas as a threatened species (EN6554)
From 5 petitioners—requesting amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (EN6556)
From 194 petitioners—requesting that Australia call on the government of Bahrain to release Dr Abduljalil Al-Singace (EN6557)
From 27 petitioners—requesting a reduction to the student contribution paid towards Commonwealth supported university places (EN6558)
From 5 petitioners—requesting the reinstatement of the visa of a long-term Australian resident (EN6565)
From 67 petitioners—requesting that equal prize money in sport be mandated (EN6567)
From 41 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a Federal Human Rights Charter (EN6568)
From 10 petitioners—regarding self-represented litigants in High Court of Australia proceedings (EN6569)
From 5 petitioners—regarding the imposition of fees by businesses (EN6572)
From 182—requesting national implementation of a law to allow families of critically ill patients to call for immediate intervention (EN6573)
From 13 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to allegations of domestic violence (EN6575)
From 628 petitioners—requesting the criminalisation of institutional coercive control (EN6576)
From 221 petitioners—regarding concerns related to the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic (EN6578)
From 1535 petitioners—requesting the cancellation of the AUKUS agreement (EN6580)
From 71 petitioners—requesting that Australia officially recognise Women, Life, Freedom Day (EN6581)
From 5 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a plan to produce and export clean energy (EN6582)
From 28 petitioners—requesting that the House debate the Human Rights (Children Born Alive Protection) Bill 2022 (EN6583)
From 248 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government impose sanctions on Israel (EN6585)
From 71 petitioners—requesting the introduction of a tax on plastics (EN6590)
From 14 petitioners—requesting the removal of taxes associated with the importation of motor vehicles (EN6595)
From 4413 petitioners—regarding federal laws relating to the age of criminal responsibility (EN6598)
From 65 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a national day to allow young people to meet Australian leaders (EN6599)
From 2 petitioners—regarding the treatment of personal information by Services Australia (EN6600)
From 51 petitioners—requesting amendments to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 to improve access to housing (EN6601)
From 26 petitioners—requesting increased funding for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and aged care in Australia (EN6602)
From 11 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to funding for the Middle Arm Sustainable Development Precinct (EN6603)
From 322 petitioners—regarding the environmental impact of the Ballymore Resources Dittmer Project (EN6605)
From 51 petitioners—requesting a transition period for students impacted by changes to the Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) (EN6610)
From 15 petitioners—requesting the inclusion of the LGBTIQ+ community in the 2026 census (EN6611)
From 8 petitioners—regarding concerns about privacy in relation to loan applications (EN6612)
From 554 petitioners—requesting permanent residency for Sri Lankan Tamil asylum seekers (EN6613)
From 146 petitioners—requesting an increase to the number of mental health sessions covered by Medicare (EN6614)
From 1241 petitioners—requesting a National Rural Health Strategy and increased support for rural health services (EN6617)
From 21 petitioners—requesting that amendments be made to the Privacy Act 1988 relating to closed-circuit television recordings and images (EN6619)
From 402 petitioners—requesting that the Spit Junction Post Office be kept open (PN0623)
From 62 petitioners—requesting that medicinal cannabis be included in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PN0624)

span.span: 2. The following 20 ministerial responses to petitions were received.
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 10 October 2024

p.span: From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting a moratorium on the installation of mobile phone base stations in residential areas (EN4182)
From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting that the Australian Government address issues of Uyghur forced labour (EN4321)
From the Minister for the Environment and Water to a petition regarding concerns related to geoengineering (EN4343)
From the Minister for the Arts to a petition requesting the establishment of an Australian Poet Laureate (EN4593)
From the Attorney-General to a petition regarding the protection of genetic information and the regulation of commercial DNA and ancestry testing (EN5342)
From the Special Minister of State to a petition requesting legislation to prohibit misinformation in political advertising (EN5609)
From the Minister for Financial Services to a petition regarding concerns related to a cashless economy (EN5967)

From the Minister for Defence Industry and Capability Delivery to a petition requesting that the Australian Government cancel all existing contracts with Elbit Systems and preclude Elbit Systems from receiving future contacts (EN5997)
From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting that the severity of criminal penalties for child sex offenders be increased (EN6118)
From the Minister for Climate Change and Energy to a petition requesting the removal of net zero targets and a reconsidered approach to environmental sustainability (EN6121)
From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting that the Taliban be proscribed as a terrorist organisation (EN6128)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting the reintroduction of validation documents for authorised amateur radio operators (EN6254)
From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting the introduction of a castle law in Australia (EN6268)
From the Minister for the Environment and Water to a petition regarding a proposal to clear vegetation for the ongoing operation of the Kin Kin Quarry (EN6301)
From the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to a petition requesting that the use of metaldehyde in slug and snail bait be prohibited (EN6309)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding access to safe drinking water (EN6350)

From the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition requesting an extension of an exemption for cruise vessels under section 11 of the Coastal Trading (Revitalising Australian Shipping) Act 2012 (EN6353)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding the availability and compounding of the medications semaglutide and tirzepatide (EN6367)
From the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition requesting legislation mandating rotating beacons and side lighting on rolling stock (EN6369)
From the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to a petition requesting the establishment of a database to monitor adverse reactions to veterinary products (EN6380)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 40 petitions:

subdebateinfo.title: Good and Services Tax: Online Purchases

p.span: Good and Services Tax: Online Purchases

Platforms such as Shein, Wish, Temu, Amazon, Ebay, Alixpress, Esty are sure cheap platforms for the general consumer, but we must understand that money earned in Australia is not staying in Australia, it is making these platforms richer and shutting down our small businesses because our money earned is not being generated within our country but being thrown overseas. Are you willing to work hard for your money to then give it all to overseas platforms?
If we keep going this way, there will be no shops to shop, see and feel products and our small businesses will die along with our retail economy.

We therefore ask the House to raise the GST to 30-40% for consumers, therefore if a consumer wishes to purchase on these platforms, then their costs will be higher and hopefully hesitant to buy online but rather shop local.
This GST raise will also be applicable to retailers but if you are GST registered you, you one can be exempt from GST cost or claim back.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN6550)
Tertiary Education

As future jobs require higher education this highlights the urgent need for enhanced Australia's educational infrastructure to meet present and future demands and address the national higher education labour gap. There is a clear demand for advanced educational opportunities to sustain and enhance the community's intellectual capital. Addressing Educational Gaps: Establishing a university specializing in high-demand sectors like Information Technology, Healthcare, Engineering, and Business will address current and future skill gaps in Australia. This institution will boost Australia's skilled workforce and fill national gaps in these essential sectors, ensuring Australia remains competitive in the global economy.

We therefore ask the House to bridge the existing "National Territory Gap" in higher education, the government must implement enhanced programs and policies that focus on equitable university funding across all regions. This gap, which reflects the disparity in access to quality education between metropolitan areas and regional, rural, or remote territories, must be closed to ensure that every student, regardless of their location, has equal opportunities for success. By adopting targeted policies and funding programs, we can promote a more inclusive and equitable higher education system that serves all students, regardless of their geographic location.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN6551)
Domestic and Family Violence

Domestic violence (DV) is a critical issue affecting countless individuals. However, there are significant challenges in addressing DV cases fairly and effectively. False accusations of DV can devastate innocent lives, leading to unjust legal and social consequences, including wrongful imprisonment. At the same time, inadequate investigation procedures can result in genuine victims not receiving the protection they need.

Currently, there is insufficient accountability for those who make false DV claims, and investigative procedures often lack the thoroughness required to ensure justice. Furthermore, many jurors are not fully educated on the fundamental legal principles of "presumption of innocence" and "beyond a reasonable doubt," which are crucial for fair trials.

We therefore ask the House to Implement Accountability Measures: Introduce legal measures to hold individuals who knowingly make false DV accusations accountable, including clear consequences to deter misuse.

Enhance Investigation Procedures: Improve training for law enforcement and investigative personnel to ensure thorough and sensitive handling of DV cases. This includes better evidence collection and victim support practices.
Educate Jurors: Establish mandatory educational programs for jurors on the principles of presumption of innocence and the standard of "beyond a reasonable doubt" to ensure fair and just trials.
By addressing these concerns, we aim to create a more just system that supports genuine victims of domestic violence while protecting the rights of the innocent.
from 220 citizens (Petition No. EN6552)
National Rugby League
A huge Wast off Australian tax dollar. The Money Can be better spent on Hospitals and homes, and the homeless problem in Australia.
We therefore ask the House to stop all tax payer funds, to be used for the 60 million a year for 10 years = 600 million dollars not to be given to Papua New Guinea rugby.
from 34 citizens (Petition No. EN6553)
Koalas

A species is considered 'Critically Endangered' if there are fewer than 50 mature individuals globally. It's 'Endangered' if there are fewer than 250 individuals, and 'Vulnerable' if there are fewer than 1,000. *National geographic Society According to CSIRO National Koala Population estimates there are somewhere between 287,830 and 628,010 in the wild.
We therefore ask the House to somehow stop those that take donations under the guise of "saving the koalas".
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6554)
Human Rights

Imagine a world without gender, race, status or age, where individuals are equal by virtue of their humanity. While Australia aspires to this ideal, our international promises under human rights instruments actually mandate this. For example, Australia's ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), creates a contract, or promise to comply, and an obligation to create multi-directional equality; to act on complaints to state police as if they are without gender, as if Australia is a place without socially constructed bias in policing.

Commonwealth Parliament is empowered by s51(xxix) of The Constitution to incorporate ICCPR true equality and multi-directional gender principles, into domestic laws. Indeed, Article 2.2 of the ICCPR mandates this. Courts will enforce these rules over state police, if Australia explicitly does this. Australia has a pressing and urgent need to render the administration of all criminal laws, and some civil laws, completely human friendly, and in that universal human rights sense, free of sex and gender bias introduced by gendered, or sexist policy thought and language
We therefore ask the House to modify Australia's Sex Discrimination Act, as follows:
1. Clarify that administrators of state laws, particularly police, are bound by the SDA;

2. Embed the principle of multi-directional gender equality, creating jurisdiction for Federal Courts to limit the powers of state police, and coerce compliance with multi-directional gender equality principles;
3. Create police targeted offences, for explicit violations of ICCPR justice, equality and universality of treatment principles.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6556)
Bahrain: Human Rights

In 2011, Bahrain sentenced Abduljalil Al-Singace to life imprisonment for participating in a pro-democracy protest. In July 2021, he began a hunger strike to protest his ill-treatment in prison and the confiscation of his manuscript on Bahraini dialects of Arabic that he spent four years writing and researching. This petition aims to raise awareness of these human rights violations and to urge the Australian government to call for his release, or at the very least, ensure he receives adequate medical attention.
We therefore ask the House to call on the Bahrain government for Dr. Al-Singace's release or minimum that he receives sufficient medical treatment.
from 194 citizens (Petition No. EN6557)
Universities

Prior to the 1970's, access to a university education was largely determined by family wealth, rather than merit. That changed in the 1970's when the Whitlam government abolished university fees. In 1989, the Hawke government reintroduced fees but at a level that ensured most working and middle class people with merit could still access university. In 2021 the Morrison government introduced the Job-ready graduates package, which significantly increases the student contribution amount and once again access to a university education largely depended on family wealth for entry to many courses. This proposal is to cap student contributions for CSP's to 10% of the median Australian annual wage.
As an example, this would reduce the student contribution for a CSP in Queensland University of Technology from the current $16,300 p.a. to $4,186p.a.

We therefore ask the House to legislate that student contributions for Commonwealth Supported Places at universities be capped at 10% of the median annual salary. In May 2023 this was $41,680 (ABS Release 2 May 2023).

Locking student contributions to the median annual wage, will ensure affordability for students and ensure that access to all Commonwealth Supported Places at university is based solely on merit and not family wealth.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN6558)
Migration

The permanent resident referred to in the title is the sole career for an elderly lady who is 87 years old, is an Australian Citizen and is impaired. Her care plan arrangements have collapsed due to her deteriorating condition. The ultimate end game is the appointment of the Public Trustee and the Public advocate to manage her affairs. This will strip her of her financial independence and ultimately force her from her home. This will be partially subsidised by the Australian taxpayer. In addition there are items missing from her home including electrical items and personal identity papers. A serious incident report has been completed but the electrical items and a number of the personal papers remain unaccounted for. There is the possibility of identity fraud and it appears that someone has attempted to obtain access to her bank accounts. Inaction in this matter has resulted in the elderly ladies front door being smashed off its hinges by the state police force. This left her without security for about 8 weeks. This is an unacceptable risk to her safety and security. The risk of this happening again is now ever-present as she lives on her own as her daughters refuse to speak to her or assist her.
We therefore ask the House to demand the relevant minister to set aside the decision in AAT matter 2023/5174 and reinstate the visa of the applicant in that matter.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6565)

subdebateinfo.title: Sport: Equal Pay for Equal Play

p.span: Sport: Equal Pay for Equal Play

We're asking the Federal Government to enact equal pay for equal play laws that rule out unequal prize money nationally and require equal opportunity, access to facilities and support for men and women athletes.
Australian women dominated the Paris 2024 Olympics. Female athletes won 13 of Australia's 18 gold medals, contributing substantially to a new record of our highest-ever gold medal tally.

Yet, sporting peak bodies, sports clubs and leagues across the country are still able to offer less prize money to women athletes. In Australia, there is no law that ensures men and women receive equal prize money for sporting competitions played at the same level.

From community levels to semi-professional leagues, prize money may be unequal between men and women—and frequently is. Many of our future female champions are also training and competing with lower-quality facilities and fewer resources. This has to change.

We therefore ask the House to require national sporting peak bodies and leagues to offer equal prize money for women and men (where/if they hold competitions involving prize money) in order to receive government funding of any kind; require community sports clubs and venues to provide equal access for men, women, boys and girls to playing, training, competition and administrative facilities across all levels of competition; and require equitable and proportionate provision of support resources such as physios and coaches for men and women athletes at all levels of competition.
from 67 citizens (Petition No. EN6567)
Human Rights
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives,

We, the undersigned, urgently petition the House to enact a Federal Human Rights Charter, ensuring consistent and equitable protection of fundamental rights across Australia. The absence of a national framework has resulted in disparities in rights protection between states, undermining the principles of fairness and equality.

A Federal Human Rights Charter is crucial to guarantee that every Australian's rights are safeguarded under a uniform federal standard. We urge Parliament to promptly pass this essential legislation, reinforcing Australia's dedication to justice, equality, and the rule of law.
We therefore ask the House to
1) Enact a Federal Human Rights Charter.
from 41 citizens (Petition No. EN6568)
Judiciary
To the Hon Speaker & Members of the House of Representatives

We, the undersigned, urgently petition the House to reform the current access requirements imposed by the High Court of Australia (HCA) on self-represented litigants. The HCA's existing threshold for lodging urgent, time-sensitive civil & criminal cases from lower courts is excessively stringent & unrealistic, even for individuals with legal expertise, such as Mr. Adrian Praljak, an admitted Australian lawyer.

This overly burdensome threshold effectively creates a barrier to justice, disproportionately impacting self-represented litigants & undermining the principle of equal access to the courts. The current system risks denying Australians the right to have their serious legal matters heard by the nation's highest court, which is contrary to the values of fairness, equality, & justice that underpin our legal system.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Review and amend the procedural and substantive requirements for self-represented litigants in the HCA, lowering the threshold to make it more accessible while maintaining judicial integrity.
2. Implement measures that provide additional support and guidance to self-represented litigants, ensuring they can navigate the complexities of the HCA without compromising their cases.

3. Ensure compliance with international legal standards, including those established by the United Nations, which affirm the right to fair and equitable access to justice for all individuals, regardless of legal representation.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN6569)
Business
Business charge late fees but when they are late they just say sorry
We therefore ask the House to make charge late fees illegal no business should be allowed to charge a late fee if it's ok for them to be late
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6572)
Health Care
Zaras rule is a necessary policy that needs to be introduced to not only Qld but Australia wide.
There is no policy that is the same in every state of Australia.
Zaras rule would benefit anyone in Emergency or on Ward that is in a critical state and not being listened to nor receiving life saving measures from medical staff.
If activated it would initiate a ICU or PICU personal from a designated zara rule team to attend the bed side of the person who called it, making an assessment of the patient infront of them.
Who is Zara?
Zara was a 21 month old little girl who was left on ward blue and her case never escalated after doctor reviews and despite Observations telling hospital staff she was deteriorating.
Ryans rule was used and the doctor that attended did not listen to zaras mum or nurses that something was seriously wrong.
After a MET call and PICU attending and working on zara for 1hr 20 mins she was placed into picu suffering 2 cardiac arrest one being 12 minutes, passing 8 days later.
Zaras Family never got the goodbyes they deserved.
Zaras Rule is needed to prevent deaths.
The Health system has changed so much in recent years yet policies haven't changed to accommodate.
Zara's Rule will save lives. It will make sure no families feel the pain Zaras Family does.
We therefore ask the House to Find a way to accommodate this rule for the whole of Australia.
from 182 citizens (Petition No. EN6573)
Domestic and Family Violence

The Dv system is by some, being abused and defrauded for financial / materials gain. The system needs to be updated to flush out the false allegations so the needed housing and monies goes to the correct persons in need. Greed is not a DV condition that the country needs.
False allegations has the potential to completely destroy a persons life and effect their mental health, for the sake of one wanting vengeance/monies and to use their children as tools.
Need more penalties and deterrents.
We therefore ask the House to change the system to erase any thoughts of wanting to defraud the system with false allegations.
1) Any time served by one and then its found to be false, time for time sentence applied.
2) Courts to look upon false claims as a act of deceit and apply criminal offences.
3) Any DV orders reversed /any breaches reversed and penalties.
4) Its covered in any family court as a mind set to protect children from them.
5) Automatic Psychology report and sessions applied.
6) Condition applied of a social media banned. (is a False allegation influencer system.)
7) Register put into place to warn other persons.
8) Reduces the worth rate for that person in any 'Civil matter".
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN6575)
Charitable Organisations: Coercive Control
Australian law only provides protection from Coercive Control within a contract, and new legislation coming into effect in 2024 only apply within domestic relationships.
However, cult-like organisations have the same characteristics and negative impacts.

In 2000, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade completed an Inquiry into Freedom of Religion and Belief. Chapter 10 notes that cults are not necessarily religious in nature, hence difficult to define a cult, and again recommended "the Commonwealth Attorney-General give consideration to the convening of an inter-faith dialogue to formulate a standard for the practices of cults."
This issue has been re-examined many times but has never resulted in any changes to the law.

We therefore ask the House to legislate against the coercive control by any organisation. No group or individual should be allowed to use deceptive, manipulative methods that restricts a person's ability to make informed decisions about their beliefs, access to information, thought processes and emotional state.

Shincheonji is a Korean pseudo-Christian cult that is currently active in Australia. Civilians are recruited through "non-denominational bible studies" and are not told who the group is until six or more months passed.

Shincheonji members has behavioural pattern that includes lying, physical exhaustion and sleep deprivation due to the activities within the group, emotional trauma, 'disciplinary' involving public verbal, emotional and physical abuse, demands for financial contributions, leaving/reducing jobs or university.
Shincheonji has been exposed by media and universities all over Australia. Australian law must change to make coercive control methods illegal by any group in Australia.
from 628 citizens (Petition No. EN6576)
COVID-19: Response
We, The Australian people have a right for the truth to be told & to tell our own stories of the impact of the Government's response to Covid 19. This has greatly impacted us all.

We therefore ask the House to hold an immediate & public Covid-19 Commission of Inquiry. This is long overdue & something the people of Australia have a right to be involved in. The Australian government's response has affected us all.
from 221 citizens (Petition No. EN6578)
Defence Procurement

The Australian people were never asked if they wanted a new $368,000,000,000 nuclear submarine deal with the USA and UK. This deal not only undermines Australia's sovereignty but creates a more dangerous world. Consensus says that most Australian citizens are against it and see it as a waste of money that could be used elsewhere.
We therefore ask the House to cancel the AUKUS agreement immediately.
from 1,535 citizens (Petition No. EN6580)
Gender Based Violence

We, the undersigned, urge the Australian Parliament to officially recognise and support the global "Women, Life, Freedom" (Jin, Jiyan, Azadi) movement. This powerful slogan, which gained international attention following the tragic death of the young Kurdish woman Jina (Mahsa) Amini in September 2022 while in the custody of the Iranian morality police, has become a symbol of resistance against the systemic oppression of women in Iran. The movement demands an end to gender-based violence, forced veiling, and the denial of basic human rights. Women in Iran who advocate for their rights face harsh penalties, including imprisonment, torture, and even execution. As Australians with family and connections in Iran, we feel the impact of these injustices and believe that Australia should stand in solidarity with this important cause

We therefore ask the House to annually recognise 16th September as "Women, Life, Freedom" Day, also known as "Jin Jiyan Azadi," and formally acknowledge this day in Parliament, recognising our heartache for our families who are enduring gender-based violence. This recognition would serve as a powerful statement of solidarity with the women and families who suffer under oppressive regimes. By acknowledging this day, Australia would join the global community in condemning gender-based violence and supporting the fight for freedom, dignity, and equal rights. It would also reinforce Australia's commitment to human rights and the values of justice and equality for all.
from 71 citizens (Petition No. EN6581)
Renewable and Clean Energy

The climate crisis is the number one threat to our prosperous future as Australians. We petition the House to establish an Australian Clean Energy Marshall Plan to accelerate our nation's transition to clean energy while boosting our economy and global influence.
This plan would:

Create an Australian Clean Energy Finance Authority to subsidise foreign demand for Australian clean energy technology and expertise, particularly in the Indo-Pacific region. This would expand markets for Australian innovations in areas like solar, wind, batteries, green hydrogen, and critical minerals processing.

Establish an Australian Critical Minerals Resilience Authority to diversify and secure supply chains for resources crucial to the clean energy transition. This would leverage Australia's abundant reserves of lithium, nickel, and rare earth elements.
Implement a carbon-based border adjustment mechanism to level the playing field for Australian industry and incentivise decarbonisation among our trading partners.
Increase expectations and funding for multilateral development banks to support clean energy projects in our region.

This plan would position Australia as a clean energy superpower, creating jobs, driving innovation, and enhancing our economic and diplomatic influence. It would also significantly contribute to global efforts to combat climate change.
We urge the House to seize this opportunity for Australia to lead on clean energy in a way that benefits our workers, businesses, regional partners, and the global climate.
We therefore ask the House to establish an Australian Clean Energy Marshall Plan.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6582)
Reproductive Autonomy
Understanding the parliament is addressing several legislative priorities, surely the life of innocent babies should rank extremely highly. One must first have life before all else.
We therefore ask the House to urgently discuss the Human Rights (Children Born Alive Protection) Bill 2022. This is literally life and death.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6583)
Israel

We have witnessed over 300 days of constant genocide committed by Israel against innocent Palestinians without so much as a slap on the wrist by Australia. They have bombed schools, hospitals, homes, even refugee tents violating the rules of law and human rights. They have forced Palestinians to relocate repeatedly to "safe zones" only to strike there as well.

When Russia invaded Ukraine, Australia was quick to levy sanctions against them, yet for over 300 days we have witnessed Gaza be turned into a mass grave whilst our government fully supports them and refuses to even consider sanctions.

We are tired of Australian ministers pathetically begging Israel to "listen to its friends" and other worthless slogans, all to nothing more than the open disregard from Israel. We are tired of being told that the situation is unacceptable, without any effort to mend said situation.
We are tired of sanctions only being levied against individuals, despite those individuals having full support and encouragement from their government.

It is insulting that even as Israeli ministers openly call for the extermination of Palestinians, our government refuses to do anything about it. Israel is clearly a rogue state with no regard for international law or even the pathetic euphemism of "rules based international order".
We are sick of our government playing dumb! We are sick of words! We are sick of our tax dollars helping to fund Israel! We are sick of complicity and support for genocide!
We therefore ask the House to immediately sanction the State of Israel
from 248 citizens (Petition No. EN6585)
Waste Management and Recycling

Plastic is destroying our planet and is to cheep so you don't give it a second thought use it once then throw it out without a second thought but with a tax on plastic you will start to think twice about it and less likely to throw it out and instead use it again or find another resource to use instead.
We therefore ask the House to implement a tax on plastic giving you more money to do something about it and a reason for people to care more about plastic.
from 71 citizens (Petition No. EN6590)
Taxation: Motor Vehicles
Australians spend more around 30% over price on cars. 20% or more (especially for so called luxury cars) are due to tarrifs and taxes, that's doesn't include the running fees.

There is no national alternative for any type of car, this is lowering the life standards of all Australians, and also affect the quality of imported cars to the country even if they meet other environmental criteria. At the end it is a machine which we buy a lower end ones because it is overpriced for no reason.

To make it a bit clear prices are so exaggerated, it's even more than european countries like UK where they have alternative national cars at affordable prices with better quality we don't have that option and yet we have to pay more.
We therefore ask the House to remove all unnecessary tax's and tariffs on cars import like
Import tariffs
Customs duty
Stamp duty
Luxury car tax

You may add taxes on large engine cars to sustain environmental and energy usage .. but all other tax and stamps are useless and affecting inflation beside the life standard of each fellow Australian.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN6595)
Youth Justice

We, the undersigned, urge the House of Representatives to reform federal legislation on child-on-child sexual abuse. Under current law, children aged 10 to 14 are presumed incapable of understanding the criminality of their actions unless proven otherwise (doli incapax). This legal presumption often prioritises the offender's rehabilitation over the victim's rights and welfare. Such an approach inadequately protects victims and fails to hold offenders accountable, leading to long-term psychological harm. Research shows that survivors of childhood sexual abuse are at a significantly higher risk of mental health issues, including depression, anxiety, PTSD, and suicide.

We therefore ask the House to amend federal laws concerning the age of criminal responsibility, ensuring they better protect victims and hold offenders accountable. We also urge the implementation of federally mandated psychological and emotional support services for victims, to be provided throughout the legal process. Additionally, a comprehensive review of the current legal framework is needed to identify and address gaps that allow offenders to evade serious consequences. These reforms are essential for protecting vulnerable children, ensuring justice, and restoring public confidence in the justice system.
from 4,413 citizens (Petition No. EN6598)
Young Australians

Australia's youth, nearly 5 million strong, are grappling with pressing challenges like the cost of living, mental health issues, and climate change. Yet, many young people feel disconnected from the decision-makers creating policies that profoundly affect our lives.

To bridge this gap, I propose a "National Youth Meet and Greet Day"—a day dedicated to bringing young Australians face-to-face with community leaders, like MPs and councillors. This initiative would create a welcoming and inclusive space where youth can share their ideas, perspectives, and concerns directly, without the fear of their ideas not being important or valuable enough.

For many young people, reaching out to leaders independently can be intimidating. By establishing this campaign, we provide an opportunity for them to make that initial connection, fostering the confidence to continue dialogues and contribute meaningfully in the future.

I envision this campaign growing into a nationwide movement, engaging leaders at every level, from local to federal government, and giving youth from all walks of life a platform to influence the decisions that affect their future. This day isn't just about a single event—it's about laying the foundation for a future where young Australians are actively involved in shaping the world we live in.
Let's make sure every young person in Australia is heard. Sign the petition, join the campaign, and together, let's create the future all young Australians deserve.
We therefore ask the House to be a part of this campaign and take action on behalf of all young Australians.
from 65 citizens (Petition No. EN6599)
Public Sector Governance
Human services

Superannuation

Australians who are renting are enduring an escalating housing crisis, with rising costs making it increasingly difficult to save for a home deposit, especially for those without the advantage of family wealth to support their future. Currently, Self-Managed Super Funds (SMSFs) are permitted to purchase commercial properties that can be leased back to the fund owner, providing a clear pathway to financial growth. However, this option is unjustly restricted when it comes to residential properties, preventing Australians from using their superannuation to secure their housing and build long-term financial stability.

This change would enable Australians to redirect the money they currently pay in rent into their superannuation, directly contributing to their wealth growth while securing stable housing. By leveraging their super funds in this way, Australians could break free from the cycle of perpetual renting, build a more secure financial future, and enjoy the stability of knowing their home won't be sold or their lease unexpectedly ended.

from 554 citizens (Petition No. EN6613)
Mental Health

Mental health challenges affect millions of Australians each year, leading to significant personal, social, and economic costs. Yet, access to effective psychotherapy remains limited due to capped Medicare funding to 10 sessions per year. Increasing government funding for mental health is essential for several reasons.

First, untreated mental health issues often escalate into crises that strain healthcare systems, law enforcement, and social services. By investing in preventive and early intervention services, the government can reduce these burdens, leading to better outcomes for individuals and communities while saving public resources in the long run.

Second, the mental health crisis disproportionately impacts vulnerable populations, including low-income individuals, minorities, and those living in rural areas. Increased funding would improve access to therapy for these groups, addressing inequalities and ensuring that all citizens have the opportunity to lead healthy, fulfilling lives.
Expanding access to these services can improve productivity, reduce disability, and enhance the overall well-being of society.

Finally, mental health is as vital as physical health. By prioritizing funding for psychotherapy, the government can demonstrate its commitment to treating mental health with the seriousness it deserves, ultimately leading to a healthier, more resilient population. Investing in mental health is not just a moral imperative; it is a wise economic decision that will pay dividends for generations to come.
We therefore ask the House to increase the Medicare funding to cover 26 mental health sessions per year.

Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 20 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Telecommunications
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 7 November 2022, regarding a petition requesting a ban on the installation of mobile phone base stations on any residential or rural residential lots due to health concerns from the community, and proposed amendments to the Industry Code for Mobile Phone Base Station Deployment C564:2020 (the Industry Code). I apologise for the delay in responding. As you may be aware, this petition was not received by my office until 25 August 2023 due to a technical error which then resulted in the petition being incorrectly archived in the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts (my department) parliamentary document management system.

While I understand the timeframe for a response to this petition has lapsed, I acknowledge the petitioners concerns and would like to reassure you and the petitioners the effects of electromagnetic energy (EME) exposure are the subject of extensive and rigorous scientific study around the world. The Australian Government strictly regulates EME emissions to protect the health and safety of all members of the public, while allowing the community to access essential modem telecommunications services.

As you may be aware, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) is an independent Government agency that is not affiliated with, or unduly influenced by, the telecommunications industry and provides advice on radiation protection to the Australian Government, including both the Department of Health and my department.

In 2021, ARPANSA updated its Radiation Protection Series (RPS) Standard for Limiting Exposure to Radiofrequency Fields—100 kHz to 300 GHz (RPS S -1), also known as the 'ARPANSA RF Standard', based on the most up-to-date Australian and international peer- reviewed research into EME. The exposure limits are based on current scientific knowledge, are aligned with international guidelines prepared by the International Commission for Non-Ionising Radiation Protection (ICNIRP), and are endorsed by the World Health Organization (WHO).

They are underpinned by several reviews of the scientific literature including: the ICNIRP review of RF EME and health, and The Scientific Committee on Emerging and Newly Identified Health Risks (SCENIHR)'s opinion on 'Potential health effects of exposure to electromagnetic fields (EMF)'. The RF Standard covers the operating frequencies of 5G infrastructure and devices. ARPANSA consulted publicly in developing its new RF Standard and provided extensive information explaining the changes.

In relation to the petitioners' concerns about 4G and 5G, there is currently no substantiated scientific evidence that exposure to radio waves from this technology at levels below the exposure limits set in the ARPANSA RF Standard causes any adverse health effects. The ARPANSA RF Standard protects people of all ages and health status against all known adverse health effects from exposure to EME by specifying emission levels that telecommunications services must operate below. The limits are set much lower than the levels where known health effects occur. Because of this requirement, there is no particular advantage in requiring telecommunications infrastructure to be located any particular distance from residential areas or community sensitive locations, such as schools. Further information about the steps taken by ARPANSA in developing its RF Standard are set out on its website at www.arpansa.gov.au/developing-arpansas-radiofrequency-safety-standard.

In addition, the Australian Communications and Media Authority (the ACMA) is an independent Commonwealth statutory authority and sets rules for the communications industry to follow based on the ARPANSA RF Standard. These rules maintain EME at safe levels and the ACMA actively monitors compliance with these rules. More information about this regulation is available at www.acma.gov.au/our-rules-eme.

Petitioners may also be interested to know the ACMA is auditing EME emissions from a selected sample of representative sites across Australia, and have compared results against the safety limit specified in the ARPANSA RF Standard. The ACMA's measurements have, to date, found all sites tested are well below the safety limit specified in the ARPANSA RF Standard. Further information is available at www.acma.gov.au/publications/2022-08/guide/eme-checker.
The following information may be useful for petitioners with concerns relating to consultation requirements for the deployment of telecommunications infrastructure in communities.

The Government expects carriers to engage with communities in a meaningful and sensitive way about proposed deployments and is responsible for the carriers' powers and immunities {P&I) framework, established under Schedule 3 of the Telecommunications Act 1997(the Act).

The P&I framework provides that carriers can install 'low-impact facilities' such as antennas and cabling, without the need for planning approvals. This framework has been in place for more than 20 years and has enabled the rollout of mobile networks and the National Broadband Network in an efficient, nationally consistent way.

Larger telecommunications infrastructure, such as towers and poles, cannot be deployed by a carrier using the P&I framework, and must be installed in accordance with local State or Territory planning laws. The Commonwealth is not involved in local or state and territory government planning processes.

The Industry Code sets out processes that mobile carriers should follow when installing low-impact facilities and other infrastructure that does not require development approval. The Industry Code is designed to ensure that stakeholders are advised before a mobile phone base station is constructed, and that council and community views are considered.

Information about proposed and current telecommunications facilities is available on the Radio Frequency National Site Archive (RFNSA), which is available for public access at www.rfnsa.com.au. This website is managed by the telecommunications industry. Interested parties can subscribe to receive information about future installations of telecommunications equipment at a particular site or area.
Any complaints about a carrier's compliance with its obligations under the Act can be made to the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) on 1300 850 115 or by email to info@acma.gov.au.

I note my department provides information on its website about the P&I framework and deployment of telecommunications equipment, and the research, regulation and safety of EME from telecommunications. The information is available at www.infrastructure.1wv.au/powers-and-immunities and www.eme.srov.au respectively.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland (Petition No. EN4182)
Human Rights: China
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to Senator the Hon Penny Wong, Minister for Foreign Affairs, regarding Petition EN4321 requesting the Government to address issues of Uyghur forced labour by passing the Customs Amendment (Banning Goods Produced By Uyghur Forced Labour) Bill 2021.

The Customs Amendment (Banning Goods Produced By Uyghur Forced Labour) Bill 2020 proposed to amend the Customs Act 1901 to prohibit the importation into Australia of goods from Xinjiang province in the People's Republic of China as well as goods from other parts of China that are produced by using forced labour. The Bill was introduced to the Australian Parliament on 8 December 2020 and was discharged from the Notice Paper on 24 June 2021.
The Australian Government considers forced labour and other forms of modem slavery, no matter where they occur, to be abhorrent crimes that have no place in our society.
Modem slavery is a serious issue and the Government is delivering on its commitment to strengthen its already comprehensive response to modem slavery at home and abroad.

The Government continues to have grave concerns about severe human rights violations in Xinjiang, including forced labour. The Prime Minister raised these concerns directly with China's Premier Li Qiang on 17 June 2024. The Government will continue to work with partners to urge China to adhere to its human rights obligations through multilateral forums. Australia made a number of strong recommendations to China during its Human Rights Council Universal Periodic Review in January 2024, including to cease coercive labour practices which discriminate against Uyghurs on the basis of race or religion.

The Government has also committed to strengthening our domestic framework to ensure the supply chains Australians use do not promote, condone or financially support forced labour, including by strengthening the Modern Slavery Act 2018 (the Act). On 28 May 2024, the Australian Parliament passed legislation to establish Australia's inaugural federal Anti-Slavery Commissioner (Commissioner) with critical core functions. The Government has committed $8 million over four years, and $2 million each year thereafter to establish the role of the Commissioner.
The Commissioner will work across Government, industry and civil society to exercise their functions, including to:
support business to address the risk of modem slavery practices in their operations and global supply chains;
engage with victims and survivors of modem slavery; and
help fight modern slavery in Australia and abroad.

The Commissioner will be a new, independent pillar of Australia's response to modem slavery and will complement Australia's existing efforts across Government, industry and civil society to combat this crime.

The Act has increased business and government awareness of modem slavery risks, including forced labour. The Act requires certain large entities to report annually and describe the risks of modem slavery in their global operations and supply chains, and any actions taken to address these risks. The Government provides support and guidance to businesses to help them report in accordance with the Act. The Government will soon respond to the statutory review of the Act in 2024 following careful consideration of the recommendations.
The Government also conducts outreach to businesses on supply chain risks, including forced labour, and the importance of due diligence in relation to addressing modem slavery.

The Government is aware of the work underway internationally to prevent goods produced using forced labour from entering markets. Cross-border mechanisms entail significant practical, administration and enforcement challenges that need careful and thorough consideration. The Government may consider ways to further strengthen Australia's response to forced labour in supply chains in line with its response to the review of the Act and in consultation with the Commissioner, once appointed.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Environment
Dear Chair
Thank you for your referral of 25 July 2023 of a petition regarding geoengineering (EN4343). I regret the time it has taken to respond.

The Australian Government is aware of geoengineering concerns, their association with 'chemtrails' and their prevalence on internet websites. These theories often suggest that the trails seen behind high level aircraft are the result of the deliberate spraying of chemical or biological agents.

The observed phenomenon is actually caused by condensation trails or 'contrails' produced by high level aircraft. These contrails, or long streams of cloud, are formed when hot engine exhaust containing water vapor, carbon dioxide, and small amounts of particles, mixes with cold surrounding air. Under the right conditions contrails can last for hours while growing to several kilometres in width and 200 to 400 metres in height. There is no evidence that contrails are harmful to human health or the environment, although they can lead to increased cloud formation.

Additional information about contrails and other emissions from an aircraft and their impact on the environment and climate is available from the US Environmental Protection Agency website at epa.gov/sites/default/files/2016-10/documents/afd-051013-001.pdf and the Air Services Australia website at www.airservicesaustralia.com/about-us/about-our-operations/condensation-trails.
Thank you again for your correspondence.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Arts and Culture

The Writing Australia Council will support this work and provide informed advice to the Australia Council Board about the responsibilities of Writing Australia. Writing Australia and the Council will commence on l July 2025.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Arts, Mr Burke
Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 August 2024, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN5342, regarding the protection of genetic information and the regulation of commercial DNA and ancestry testing.

The Government acknowledges the concerns around the use of genetic information provided for DNA testing. It is vital that Australia's privacy laws properly protect our personal information, and that they keep pace with technological developments and global standards.

The Privacy Act 1988 (Privacy Act) protects the privacy of Australians by regulating the collection, use, disclosure and storage of personal information. It contains the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs) which apply to Australian Government agencies and private sector organisations with an annual turnover of over $3 million. In 2006, the Privacy Act was amended to safeguard the handling of genetic information by changing the definition of 'health information' and 'sensitive information' to expressly include genetic information. The Privacy Act applies to businesses incorporated in Australia, and businesses outside Australia where they carry on a business in Australia.

Under the APPs, an entity can only use or disclose personal information (which includes health information and sensitive information) for a purpose for which it was collected (known as the 'primary purpose'), or for a secondary purpose if an exception applies (APP 6). Entities must take reasonable steps to protect personal information that they hold from misuse, interference and loss, as well as unauthorised access, modification or disclosure (APP 11), and, before disclosing personal information to an overseas recipient, must take reasonable steps to ensure that the overseas recipient does not breach the APPs in relation to the information (APP 8). More information on individuals' privacy rights, as well as information on how to make a privacy compliant, is available on the website of the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC), Australia's privacy regulator, at: https://www.oaic.gov.au/.

The Government is committed to strengthening existing privacy protections. The Attorney-General's Department's comprehensive review of the Privacy Act was released in February 2023. The report, available online at www.ag.gov.au/rights-and- protections/publications/privacy-act-review-report, made a number of reform proposals, including to require entities to handle personal information fairly and reasonably, to enhance notice and consent requirements, and to provide a right for individuals to request that their personal information be erased.

This review included a proposal to amend the Privacy Act to require entities to handle personal information fairly and reasonably, entities would be required to handle personal information in a way in which Australians reasonably expect. This test would apply regardless of whether an individual has indicated their consent, meaning entities would not be able to use consent as a shield for inappropriate privacy practices.
This test would set a baseline of protections to give Australians confidence should they choose to provide their data to commercial DNA and ancestry testing entities.

The Government's Response to the review, published in September 2023 and available online at www.ag.gov.au/rights-and-protections/publications/government-response-privacy- act-review-report. agreed or agreed in-principle to progress the vast majority of proposals.

On 12 September 2024, I introduced the Privacy and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2024 into Parliament. The Bill would legislate a first tranche of proposals agreed to in the Government Response to the review, as well as introduce a statutory t01t for serious invasions of privacy, and criminal offences for the malicious release of an individual's personal data online, also known as doxxing.

The Government is committed to ensuring the Privacy Act works for all Australians and is fit for purpose in the digital age. This legislation is just the first stage of the Government's commitment to provide individuals with greater control over their personal information. The Government will continue to advance proposals that it agreed in principle to progress in its Response to the review, through targeted consultation with stakeholders on draft provisions. This targeted consultation will inform the Government's decisions on next steps and a future package of reforms.
I trust this info1mation is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Political Advertising
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your petition of 12 February 2024 requesting truth in political advertising legislation be implemented for elections.

The Government is committed to strengthening the transparency of our electoral system and maintaining voter confidence in elections. Electoral reform is complex and requires consultation across the Parliament. As such, the parliament's multi-partisan Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) is the appropriate forum for proposed electoral changes to be investigated and considered.

After JSCEM was constituted for this parliament, I requested its consideration of matters relating to the 2022 federal election. One of the issues I specifically asked for inquiry into was the potential for 'truth in political advertising' laws to enhance the integrity and transparency of the electoral system. In its interim report, JSCEM recommended the Government legislate to govern truth in political advertising.
The Government is carefully considering these recommendations and is pursuing multi- partisan support for legislative reform to strengthen our electoral system.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention. Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Mr Farrell (Petition No. EN5609)
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5967 on businesses and banks becoming cashless.
The Government understands the important role cash still plays in our payments system and supports Australians having continued access to cash.

The use of cash as a method of payment has been declining for many years due to changing consumer preferences and advances in technology. This long-nm trend has been reinforced by changes in payment behaviour arising from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Nonetheless, cash is an important payment method for certain groups and plays a vital role in their inclusion in the wider economy. Cash is still widely accepted as a means of payment by merchants, used as a store of value, and provides resilience to the payments system during outages where digital forms of money cannot be used.

On 7 June 2023, the Government released its Strategic Plan for Australia's Payments System (the Plan), which details the policy priorities and objectives of the Government in relation to payments. One of the initiatives in the Plan was 'Maintaining adequate access to cash'. As part of this, the Government will work with relevant agencies across the public sector and with industry to ensure that Australia has a sustainable cash distribution network that maintains adequate access to cash. The Plan is available online at www.treasury.gov.au/sites/default/files/2023-06/p2023-404960.pdf.

Cash, however, is not always the best means of payment for a business to accept and can add to their costs. This is a commercial decision for businesses who are able to specify what forms of payment they will accept prior to entering into a transaction. While these are commercial decisions, the Government is monitoring the situation to ensure vulnerable Australians are able to access the essential goods and services they need.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Defence Procurement
Dear Chair

Thank you for your referral of 14 May 2024 regarding the House of Representatives Petition EN5997—Ban Elbit Systems from Australian Government Contracts. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Australia remains gravely concerned about the dire humanitarian situation in Gaza. We continue to press for a ceasefire, the protection of civilians and for hostages to be released immediately. The Government has committed more than $72 million for humanitarian assistance to the Middle East since 7 October 2023 and continues to call for safe, unimpeded and sustained access for humanitarian workers. We have made clear that international law must be observed in all contexts.

As you may be aware, I addressed the House on 6 June 2024, and advised there is significant misinformation concerning the contracting arrangements for the LAND 400 Phase 3 Infantry Fighting Vehicle program. Hanwha Defence Australia (Hanwha) was selected by the Australian Government to build and deliver the Redback Infantry Fighting Vehicles for the Australian Defence Force (ADF). This program will deliver critical capability to the ADF and support local Australian jobs, and manufacturing in our defence industry.

Hanwha has made a commercial decision to sub-contract work associated with the turret system to Elbit Systems. The Australian Government has no direct relationship with Elbit Systems with respect to this contract. Moreover, the components manufactured under this contract are solely for Australian needs, not for export elsewhere.

Australia has not supplied weapons to Israel since the conflict began, and for at least the past five years. Australia has a stringent export control framework, which is designed to ensure our military and dual-use items are used responsibly outside Australia. Defence undertakes a rigorous assessment of each application against a range of legislated criteria, including with respect to Australia's human rights and international obligations.
Like more than 160 countries, Australia continues to maintain a bilateral relationship with Israel. This involves maintaining our bilateral economic, trade and investment ties.
Thank you again for your referral of the petition, and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence Industry and Capability Delivery, Mr Conroy
Child Abuse
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 regarding a petition (reference EN6118) to increase penalties for child sex offenders and consider legalising the death penalty.
The Australian Government understands that for those who have lived experience of child sexual abuse, speaking out takes bravery.

Firstly, the petition calls for increased severity of sentencing for child sexual abuse offences. For child sexual abuse offences that are held by the states and territories, the federal government is unable to prescribe the severity of penalties for these offences. Where child sexual abuse offences are considered Commonwealth-level offences, the Australian Government continues to work with the criminal justice system to ensure it is equipped to independently deliver the most appropriate penalties in these cases. On 13 March 2024, the High Court handed down judgment that confirmed that mandatory minimum sentencing provisions under sections 16AAA, 16AAB, and 16AAC of the Crimes Act 1914 will apply for Commonwealth child sexual abuse offences, and will operate as yardsticks for the appropriate te1m of imprisonment for the offence in the least serious circumstances.

Secondly, the petition calls for a national debate to legalise the death penalty and apply it to these offence types. The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that serious crimes are met with appropriate penalties, but has a long-standing policy of opposition to capital punishment. As a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and its Second Optional Protocol, Australia has an obligation not only to abolish the death penalty in its jurisdiction, but also to ensure that our laws and policies are consistent with this obligation.

In March 2010, the Commonwealth Parliament passed laws to extend the application of the prohibition on the death penalty to the States and Territories. This ensures that the death penalty cannot be reintroduced anywhere in Australia in the future.

The Australian Government, however, is committed to ensuring that victims and survivors of child sexual abuse are supported and empowered. The Government has a commitment to measures that reduce, and ultimately end, the prevalence of child sexual abuse offences in Australia.

Under the National Strategy to Prevent and Respond to Child Sexual Abuse 2021-2030, a number of initiatives are underway across a variety of areas, including under the themes of 'offender prevention and intervention' and 'supporting and empowering victims and survivors' amongst others.
I trust this info1mation is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Climate Change
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 3 June 2024 regarding petition number EN6121 regarding removing net zero targets and reconsidering approaches to environmental sustainability.

Governments and communities around the world recognise the challenge and risks of climate change and are acting to transform their economic activities and reduce emissions. These actions are formalised in the Paris Agreement, to which Australia is a party. The only United Nations members not yet a party to the Paris Agreement are Iran, Libya and Yemen (each of which has signed, but not yet ratified). More than 160 countries, including the world's largest economies—China, the United States, India and the European Union—have net-zero targets, covering about 89 per cent of global emissions and 94 per cent of global GDP.

In 2022, the Parliament legislated Australia's greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets, to reach net zero by 2050 and to reduce emissions to 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. Building on that momentum, the Government has committed to developing a Net Zero Plan and six sectoral decarbonisation plans which will articulate how Australia will transition to a net zero economy, consistent with our international and domestic commitments. Investors, industry, unions and other stakeholders have called for a clear and credible net zero plan with sectoral detail and welcomed the Government's sectoral planning approach. Government has a key role to set clear direction and provide a stable policy framework for Australia's transition to net zero.

By setting and working to achieve targets, Australia is participating in the most significant structural change in the world economy since the industrial revolution. If we are to continue to participate in the global economy and remain relevant and competitive, Australia must continue to take strong and credible action to reduce our emissions. The Government's Future Made in Australia policy framework will help us become a renewable energy superpower and an indispensable part of the global economy.

Australia's net zero targets, enabling legislation and supporting policies introduced by this Government are already achieving real emissions reductions. The most recent National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Quarterly Update shows emissions in the year to March 2024 were 28.2 per cent below emissions in 2005. And our emissions projections indicate committed policies put us on track to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 42 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030—well within reach of our legislative target.

Decarbonising the transport sector is a critical step in reducing whole of economy emissions. The Australian Government recognises the importance of public electric vehicle charging infrastructure in our transition to decarbonise the transport sector. At the end of 2023, there were around 800 ultra-DC fast charging locations operating nationwide, supporting 2,000 fast and ultra-fast charging plugs-an increase of over 70 per cent in a year. Over the next 12-36 months, an additional 1,000 new fast charging locations are expected to be opened across the country.

In addition to this investment, the National Electric Vehicle Fast Charging Network is being delivered by the National Roads and Motorists' Association (NRMA) with a $39.3 million grant from the Government to deliver 117 public fast charging stations along key highway routes across Australia, at an average interval of 150 km.

Studies of the full vehicle lifecycle emissions (manufacture, operation, and end-of-life) found lifecycle emissions of battery electric vehicles are around 36 to 80 per cent less than comparable combustion engine vehicles, depending on the share of renewable energy in the electricity grid. Switching to electric vehicles will also help to reduce air pollution providing wide-ranging health and environmental benefits.
I trust my response will help explain the task we have undertaken as a nation and why targets, and the measures to achieve them, are necessary and in the best interests of all Australians.
Thank you for bringing the concerns expressed through the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
National Security
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Penny Wong, regarding petition number EN6l28. Your letter has been referred to me for reply as the issues raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities as Attorney-General.

The Australian Government takes advice from security and intelligence agencies about whether organisations meet the criteria for listing as terrorist organisations under Division 102 of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code). In accordance with long-standing practice, the Government does not comment on whether specific organisations are being considered for listing as a terrorist organisation.

Australia has joined international calls for the Taliban to uphold the human rights of all Afghans. Australia's engagement with the Taliban is limited, and only as required to prosecute our interests. Australia implements United Nations Security Council (UNSC) Resolution 1988, which maintains the Taliban sanctions regime, through the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945 and its regulations. This framework reaffirms the UNSC's strong concern about the security situation in Afghanistan, in particular the potential for Afghanistan to be used as a base for cross-border tenorist activities. The UNSC Taliban sanctions regime imposes the following sanctions measures:
restrictions on supplying arms and related materiel;
restrictions on providing services related to military activities;
restrictions on providing assets to designated persons or entities;
restrictions on dealing with the assets of designated persons or entities; and
travel bans on designated persons.

Islamic State-Khorasan Province was listed as a terrorist organisation on 3 November 2017 under Division 102 of the Criminal Code. The Government re-listed Islamic State-Khorasan Province on 3 November 2023 to reflect the continuing threat it poses to the region.
Thank you again for bringing your concerns to the Government's attention, and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Amateur Radio Licences
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 1 July 2024 on behalf of 1342 signatories regarding Petition EN6254, which requests that the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) is directed to restore the practice of issuing an appropriate and acceptable validation document to authorised Australian amateur radio operators.
I recognise the importance of amateur radio operators being able to appropriately demonstrate that they can operate an amateur radio station and call sign both in Australia and overseas.

The ACMA is the statutory authority with responsibility for regulating radiocommunications services in Australia. This includes responsibility for regulating and licensing use of the radiofrequency spectrum by amateur radio operators. On 19 February 2024, the new Radiocommunications (Amateur Stations) Class Licence 2023 (class licence) commenced to replace the previous non-assigned apparatus licensing arrangement for amateur radio operators (amateurs). The class licence was introduced after extensive consultation with the amateur radio community to reduce the cost, complexity and regulatory burden of the previous non-assigned apparatus licence.

The previous non-assigned apparatus licensing arrangements required the ACMA to issue a licence document to individual amateurs for a fee. The new class licence no longer requires the issue or renewal of a licence or payment of a licence fee. After the implementation of the class licence, amateurs previously holding an apparatus licence could continue to operate under the class licence if they had a recognised qualification and a call sign.

To manage the transition between the two licensing arrangements, the ACMA issued a 'Letter of Confirmation' to all non-assigned amateur apparatus licensees prior to the introduction of the class licence. This letter provided details on the transition, implications for licensing, as well as the highest qualification level and any 2, 3 or 4-letter call signs assigned to the individual amateur.

The ACMA obtained agreement from the European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations (CEPT), and its member states, that the Letter of Confirmation could be used as proof that amateurs can continue to operate under the class licence, with reciprocal licensing arrangements updated accordingly.

When the ACMA assigns a call sign after 19 February 2024 under the class licensing framework, the ACMA provides a call sign ce1tificate to the amateur. The Petitioners raise a concern about the ACMA declining to issue a call sign certificate to amateurs who formerly held an apparatus licence, which the Petitioners consider would be a suitable replacement for the now withdrawn apparatus licence document. The Petition suggests that the Letter of Confirmation has been shown to be inadequate in both content and appearance for validation purposes, and does not adequately confirm that a valid licence or call sign is currently held by the amateur.

The ACMA has advised that the Letter of Confirmation, which is also recognised by the CEPT and its member states under reciprocal licencing arrangements, is sufficient for amateurs to appropriately demonstrate that they can continue to operate under the class licence. Further, the issue of an additional call sign certificate is likely to introduce confusion about how amateurs can demonstrate that they can operate under the class licence, and would be contrary to the purpose of the class licence to reduce regulatory burden and simplify the regulatory framework.

While it is acknowledged that the new class licence arrangement has resulted in a change of practice for some amateurs and stakeholders, the ACMA continues to engage individually with amateurs, other regulators, and organisations that provide services to amateurs, to answer any questions about the new class licence arrangements.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Security Legislation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 12 August 2024 which referred the petition to introduce Castle Law in Australia under Standing Orders 209(a) and (b).

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring the safety of all Australians. Under Australia's federal system, the Commonwealth, states and territories have different responsibilities with respect to criminal law. The proposal in the petition for expanded self-defence laws is most likely to engage state or territory laws such as crimes against the person (e.g. assault, aggravated assault or murder) or property (e.g. robbery, theft, trespass). These are appropriately a matter for the states and territories.

Section 10.4 of the Commonwealth Criminal Code provides for the defence of self-defence as it applies in relation to Commonwealth criminal offences. Section 10.4 balances a person's right to defend themselves with force, where required, in the circumstances set out under subsection 10.4(2), whilst requiring that any response is reasonable in the circumstances. Self-defence does not apply where force is used to intentionally inflict death or really serious injury to protect property, prevent criminal trespass or remove a person who was committing criminal trespass.
The Australian Government is not proposing to extend the self-defence provisions in the Criminal Code.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus (Petition No. EN6268)
Kin Kin Quarry
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence in relation to Petition EN6301, concerning the proposal by Cordwell Resources Pty Ltd to clear vegetation for the ongoing operation of the Kin Kin Quarry, Queensland.

This project was referred for consideration under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) on 31 August 2023. The department is currently awaiting further information from the proponent before a decision can be made on whether or not the proposed action requires assessment under the EPBC Act.
